text: hi I'm kit Seeley with the New York
Times and we're here at the XL Center in
st. Paul we were here for mrs. Palin's
big speech probably the highlight of the
convention it was much anticipated she
had I think three main tasks she wanted
to introduce herself to the audience she
really wanted to take Barack Obama down
a peg or two and then of course to
promote John McCain the presidential
nominee she starts out talking about her
own biography and introducing herself to
the audience our family has the same ups
and downs as any other the same
challenges and the same joys I was just
your average hockey mom and signed up
for the PTA before I became governor of
the great state of Alaska I was mayor of
my hometown she used her small-town
upbringing as a way not only to
introduce herself but to draw a really
stark contrast with Barack Obama i guess
a small-town mayor is sort of like a
community organizer except that you have
actual responsibilities
we tend to prefer candidates who don't
talk about us one way in Scranton and
another way in San Francisco when the
stadium lights go out and those
styrofoam Greek columns are hauled back
to some studio lot
when that happens what exactly is our
opponents plan one of the big questions
coming in to the speech tonight was
whether governor Palin would be able to
attack the opposition and I think what
you saw is that she's very comfortable
in that role and then of course the
other big task she had was promoting
John McCain as the top of the ticket in
politics there are some candidates who
use change to promote their careers and
then there are those like John McCain
who use their careers to promote change
our nominee doesn't run with the
Washington heard he's a man who's there
to serve his country and not just his
party a leader who's not looking for a
fight but sure isn't afraid of one
either the speech was really well
received here in the hall it was aimed
at the people here these are the social
conservatives of the party but the big
question is going to be obviously how
voters at home viewed this voters tell
us consistently in polls that the vice
presidential candidate really doesn't
matter so even though there's been a lot
of hoopla over the last few days about
mrs. Palin voters really want to see the
presidential nominee
